The annual Women’s Welcome Reception brings together 1st and 2nd year Johnson women with women faculty and staff. During the reception at the beautiful A.D. White House, students were introduced to faculty and staff, enjoyed refreshments and reconnected after the summer. You can check out more photos in our Facebook album!

We had an inspiring day hearing from industry experts and meeting empowering women from business schools and the tech sector. Thanks to everyone for making Johnson Women in Tech 2018 so memorable!

Cornell trustees and members of Cornell University Council applaud the Johnson family at the October 1984 announcement of Sam and Gene’s gift to name the Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management.⠀
Read more about the Johnson legacy and the new SC Johnson College of Business at the link in our bio.

"The reason I chose Johnson was because it not only welcomes original and unconventional perspectives, but it also offers opportunities for students to pursue positions that have significant social impact on the environment and community." —André Hook, MBA/MHA ’18⠀
Hook had the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to join Cleveland Clinic’s International Operations department and contribute to their global mission thanks to our Social Impact Internship Fund. The fund provides MBAs who take a low or no-compensation summer internship in social or environmental impact with financial support.⠀
Read more about Hook, his internship, and the Social Impact Internship Fund at the link in our bio!⠀

"In the military realm, you're rewarded for selflessness and ostracized for self-promotion," says Army veteran and Cornell MBA Peter Sukits. But when you decide to apply for b-school, "You need to make sure people know about your great academic performance and experiences," which, Peter adds, "is one of the single most difficult concepts with which newly separated veterans must come to grips."

What do you do when your bae goes to b-school? From spinning to book clubs, read Emily Hampton's partner survival guide and learn how Joint Ventures at Johnson makes sure that everyone has a place within our campus community. Link in our bio!⠀

"More than any other school, I had multiple and significant conversations with Johnson students, alumni, and admissions. As I began to learn about Johnson, alumni made themselves available to describe their experience. As I filled out my application, the admissions team was willing to be a sounding board as I sorted through my ideas. As I made my final decision, current students reached out to me (in droves!) to help assure that this was the right place for me. All these experiences helped me realize that I am part of an awesome family." -Earl Roach III,

Congratulations to everyone who took home an award at this morning's Dean's Awards Brunch! Check out the full list of recipients at the link in our bio.

“The HK trek was a great opportunity for me to learn more about the city of Hong Kong. Besides being one of the financial centers and fastest-growing regions of the world, Hong Kong is a very international, open-minded, and energetic city with lots of good food and amazing scenic spots. I was able to visit the Asia headquarters of Bulge Bracket Investment Banks, investment companies, and tech start-ups during the trek, and also met lots of helpful alumni at the HK trifecta. The one week I spent in Hong Kong for my thanksgiving break was definitely the highlight of my first semester in MBA.” -Christina Wu, MBA '18
.
.
.

As an international student, Fayrouz Hares, MBA '18, searched for a program that would provide her both academic exploration and self-comfort. Leaving Morocco was a new beginning for Hares, as she had to leave behind her family who has been invested in her education since her primary school days. “I thought it was a marketing ploy at first when they talked about a ‘tight-knit community,’” chuckles Hares as she reveals why she chose Johnson. “But once I joined the community, I saw that everyone really is involved in your well-being.” ⠀
Read why Hares decided to leave Morocco to pursue her MBA, how the unyielding support from her classmates has made her experience in America worthwhile, and how she aims to lead on an international scale, at the link in our bio.⠀

“It is all about bridging that gap between two of the most important and impactful economies today.” -Morgan Alexander Jones, MBA ’15⠀
As the COO of US-China Strong, Jones combines his MBA training with a deep knowledge of Chinese culture to oversee all parts of the organization’s activities, work with strategic partners in both China and the United States, and make sure that the nonprofit’s vision is effectively communicated to the general public. Read more about Jones and his life after Johnson in this alumni profile - link in our bio! ⠀

MBAs at Gyeongbokgung Palace in Seoul, South Korea 🇰🇷 ⠀
Students in NBA 5920 are visiting Japan and South Korea to immerse themselves in the business environment. The corporate visits are put in the context of current economic, political, and social issues in each country, and to compare and contrast business operations in the two countries.⠀

We had only known each other for four months, yet as the classes came together to raise over $6,000 and 75 bed sheets to support this cause, I knew I was surrounded by an incredible group of people." -Tamar Halevi, EMBA Metro NY ‘18, Director of North American Sales Strategy at Frito-Lay⠀

There’s more to earning an MBA than meets the eye. Gina Tucker,

"My favorite class was microeconomics with Professor Waldman. I really enjoyed his teaching style, I think he's a very gifted lecturer and I really appreciated the time he put into teaching the class. There was a review session before the midterm, which some professors would assign TAs to manage, but he did it himself and he was there for four or five hours in the evening till about 10 o'clock at night on a Saturday. That kind of dedication in a professor is almost rare, I would say, because often professors are so focused on their research that they often let their teaching responsibility slide or at least minimize them. That's not the case for professor Waldman and other Johnson professors and that's definitely appreciated." -Igor Chudinov, MBA '18⠀

Our annual Community Impact Charity Auction raised over $17,000 for three charities selected by the Johnson community—Food Bank of the Southern Tier, Cancer Center of Ithaca, and the Ithaca Community Childcare Center! Thanks to everyone who donated and help Johnson make a difference. ⠀
The Johnson Community Impact organization strengthens the Ithaca community through volunteering and promoting socially responsible business.⠀⠀

It's been a rainy couple of weeks here in Ithaca, but

"Last semester the Office of Diversity and Inclusion organized an event called Sandwiches at Sage—a small lunch gathering that brings together women and women faculty. I attended Sandwiches at Sage with Risa Mish, and the experience was amazing. Having such an accomplished, smart person take an hour of her time to share her wisdom on her life as a corporate lawyer, and as a woman, is priceless. She spoke frankly about the challenges and decisions we will be facing in our post-MBA careers and gave us advice and insights that no textbook could have ever given us." -Natalia Solano Gutierrez, MBA ’17⠀

"I don’t think that many people know that I started my career out as a high school teacher. After graduating from college, I lived on a boarding school campus in Connecticut, taught algebra and geometry, and coached a few sports. I was looking for different challenges and experiences from my professional life, which is why I changed jobs afterward, but it taught me a lot about leadership and responsibility very early on. Why somebody decided that 23-year-old me could be trusted with the education of high-schoolers is beyond me, but I am grateful for the things that I took away from that experience." -Crosby Fish, Two-Year MBA '18

"I love how classes at Johnson are so interactive. Before I came to Johnson I was doing project management. My background is in computer engineering so I was learning business concepts just by experiencing them. Then I came here and learned operations management and suddenly realized that there are much more efficient ways of doing things. The classes provide great insights into what goes on in real life and it's very applicable." -Shreya Bajaj, Two-year MBA '18⠀

After being inspired by Anne Frank's quote, "No one has to wait, but can start right now to gradually change the world," alumni Matt Ronen (MBA '11) decided to follow his dream and formed @servicecorpsorg. Service Corps' goal is to empower the most talented emerging leaders to tackle society's toughest challenges. Read more about Ronen's business, how you can get involved in Service Corps, and his life after Johnson in our most recent Startup Snapshot. Link in our bio! .⠀

Pursuing your MBA as part of the

Yesterday we welcomed another group of MBA candidates to our Johnson Leadership Exploration and Assessment Day (LEAD) event! ⠀
⠀
LEAD events occur during the application process and provide us the chance to get to know top candidates in a more thorough way, while candidates get a deeper understanding of what makes Johnson so unique. This allows us to offer prospective students admission and inform them of scholarship opportunities like the Park, Forte, Consortium, ROMBA fellowships and Nolan Scholarship for Veterans!
📷: @judi_byers⠀

.

Did you know the Management Library used to be Cornell's first botany greenhouse? Opened in 1882, the five wood-framed greenhouses were collectively called the Sage Conservatory. The greenhouses were held at different temperatures to provide varied growing conditions for many rare and exotic plants used by the Botany Department for teaching and research.

The Integrative Case Competition, sponsored by @libertymutual serves as a first semester capstone project for all first year MBAs. It requires students to leverage the functional knowledge, team collaboration, decision making ability, and presentation skills they have gained during their first semester at Johnson.
Congratulations to the team 40, Yifan Chen, Jordan Malouf, Matt Muskin, Austin Piech, and Andres Quintanilla for winning the 2016 competition! It was a fantastic way to end the semester and see how every team's hard work has paid off.

"Conquering my fear of public speaking was a huge personal win here. I’ve always worked behind the scenes in theater and film and lead more collaboratively than on an assertive, individual level. Being able to get up in front of a room of 50 senior executives at the Marketing Executive Coaching Program or 200 of my classmates last semester would have sounded like an absolute nightmare to me pre-MBA. Feeling supported by my peers and professors to just prepare, stay calm, and know I could speak confidently and persuasively in front a large crowd of respected colleagues has had a huge impact on my sense of achievement here at school." - Alex Baliño, Two-Year MBA ’18

Marcelo de la Garza, MBA '18, and his family at the summit of Cascade Mountain.⠀
When applying to business schools, Marcelo was looking for a place that was family-friendly, inspired him to study, and had plenty of outdoor activities.
.⠀
.⠀
.⠀
.⠀

"Generally we think of an MBA as just a way to improve professional skills, build an alumni network, get a job, be successful in future life et cetera, et cetera. But for me personally what I've gained and what sets Cornell MBA apart from everything else, is family. Believe it or not I hang out with my classmates so much, I love them, I think this is family for life. And I can't believe I'm just 3 months away from graduation. I've spent the most precious times, the most depressing times, the most happy and satisfying moments of my life with my classmates. This is what family's all about. They've always been with me, they've always stood for me and I've stood for them. The support and the alumni network will be at any MBA school but something that I will sincerely take away from Johnson is a family." -Saurin Kamdar, MBA '17⠀
📷: @peter.x.su ⠀

Jagged mountain peaks, hiking, and unpredictable weather might not describe the typical Sage Hall classroom, but for two weeks Johnson students traded the comforts of campus for the mountains of Patagonia to take part in Johnson's Leadership Expedition.
The expedition gives students a chance to support each other's leadership development by experiencing ambiguity and adversity, taking turns assuming full responsibility for the entire group and receive real-time feedback and coaching on their leadership efforts. In short, this is a chance for students to practice, rather than just talk about, real leadership.

What's an experience you've had at Johnson that best describes the culture of the school?
"During winter break, second years helped us first years prepare for consulting recruiting. They were helping on Christmas Eve and Christmas day when they could be with their family and relaxing. We did everything over Skype and I was surprised because time outside of school is precious but everyone was so open and helpful. I think that was really representative of the culture and just how we help our peers." -Matheus S.P. Costa, two-year MBA '18

📷via @betvets, a message from Anthony Garcia, MBA '09: I'm Anthony Garcia. I made the decision to leave the Army in May 2006. At the time I had completed my second tour to Iraq, was now an instructor at the U.S. Army Medical Department Officer Basic Course, and had very few friends who had transitioned to the private sector. I was nervous, afraid, but excited for the possibilities. I had no idea what I would do or what to expect. A few weeks after making the decision, my father recommended business school. Not knowing a thing about the process, I simply applied, submitted a resume, took the GMAT, and held my breath for an acceptance letter. What I soon discovered was I was waitlisted or declined by all schools. One morning I received a message that Cornell's MBA program would be hosting a webinar for all waitlisted students. I attended and got an idea of what I should do to make my application more favorable. I decided to purchase a flight to Ithaca, NY, for the following week and schedule a meeting with the Dean of Admissions. I remember arriving to the Cornell campus in March 2006, to be welcomed by three feet of snow. I really had no idea what I was going to say, except, "Can I attend your program?" The following morning I put on a suit, drove to campus, and positioned myself in the waiting room of the admissions office. The Assistant Dean greeted me and took me to lunch at the Hospitality school hotel. She was very pleasant, we chatted, and she asked me a few questions. At the end of our meal she said, "Congratulations, you have been accepted to be a member for the Cornell Johnson School of Business Class of 2009." This was just the beginning of professionals in the private sector taking a

Agata Kostecka (MBA '11) is helping to make sustainability a way of life for stakeholders at @GapInc as the Senior Manager for Sustainability Sourcing Strategy in Hong Kong. ⠀
Kostecka loves living Hong Kong. “You’re in the middle of a major metropolis,” she says, “but it’s a 20-minute bus ride to a beach or beautiful green hillside.” She stays in touch with Johnson classmates located all over the world, especially those with whom she did the Sustainable Global Enterprise immersion. “We’re a tight cohort and we keep close.”⠀
Read more about Kostecka, her role at Gap, and her life after Johnson in her Alumni Profile at the link in our bio! http://bit.ly/2lor9yw⠀

Interested in sustainability? Established in 2003, Johnson’s Center for Sustainable Global Enterprise is a world-class academic institution producing and disseminating relevant knowledge for managers seeking innovative, profitable business opportunities which address global sustainability challenges and helps to transform the impacts of private enterprise on the world. ⠀
Learn more about the center, their incredible work, and immersion at the link in our bio! .⠀

As someone who is passionate about the intersection of food, business, and sustainability, Selina Ang (MBA ’12) found her calling as the head of business development at Ox Verte. Ox Verte specializes in business lunches with their “grain bowls” that combine grains with greens, vegetables, proteins, and condiments.⠀
“Our mission is to make real food easily accessible to people who have client meetings, all-hands staff meetings, or other group events” -Selina Ang

EMBA, Johnson Cornell Tech MBA, and One Year MBA Ithaca mix and mingle at Johnson Art Museum

"I was accepted into Johnson on February 18th. I was at work and coming out of a meeting that had exhausted me. It was around 10:30 AM and my phone started ringing and it was an Ithaca number. My heart instantly dropped and sheer panic came over me. I had no idea what they were going to say! Eddie called to let me know that I was accepted. As soon as I got off the phone I started jumping up and down in my cubicle and my boss and coworkers took me to lunch to celebrate. That day definitely goes down as one of the best days for me so far." -Sydney Starke, two-year MBA '18
